comment.text: OK with simple-mtpfs and my phone.

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem:
A new release libmtp-1.1.12 has been released. It resolves known problems, like connecting a Samsung Galaxy S7 via mtp. This does not work with libmtp-1.1.11.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
libmtp-1.1.11

How reproducible:
Always

Actual results:
Last version is available, though not wrapped for Fedora

Expected results:
Last version available in Fedora

This bug appears to have been reported against 'rawhide' during the Fedora 26 development cycle.
Changing version to '26'.
1.1.13 is out already. If there's no reply in a week, I'll start the unresponsive maintainer procedure.

bugs.title: CVE-2017-9831 libmtp: Integer overflow in ptp_unpack_EOS_CustomFuncEx

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2017-9831 libmtp: Integer overflow in ptp_unpack_EOS_CustomFuncEx

long_desc.thetext:
An integer overflow vulnerability in the ptp_unpack_EOS_CustomFuncEx function of the ptp-pack.c file of libmtp (version 1.1.12 and below) allows attackers to cause a denial of service (out-of-bounds memory access) or maybe remote code execution by inserting a mobile device into a personal computer through a USB cable.

Upstream bug report:

https://sourceforge.net/p/libmtp/mailman/message/35727918/

Created libmtp tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1465044]


Created libmtp11 tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: epel-6 [bug 1465045]

Created libgphoto2 tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1466791]

Statement:

Red Hat Product Security has rated this issue as having Low security impact. This issue is not currently planned to be addressed in future updates. For additional information, refer to the Issue Severity Classification: https://access.redhat.com/security/updates/classification/.

Patches:
https://sourceforge.net/p/libmtp/code/ci/aa7d91a789873a9d86969028e57f888a1241c085/
https://github.com/gphoto/libgphoto2/commit/203df81b9d97e820411e1eb94ae08139af73bbd0
https://github.com/gphoto/libgphoto2/commit/e25b3983489cd290edef693e78c0af694d3cd010

comment.text: OK with simple-mtpfs and my phone.

bugs.title: CVE-2017-9832 libmtp: Integer overflow in ptp_unpack_OPL function

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2017-9832 libmtp: Integer overflow in ptp_unpack_OPL function

long_desc.thetext:
An integer overflow vulnerability in ptp-pack.c (ptp_unpack_OPL function) of libmtp (version 1.1.12 and below) allows attackers to cause a denial of service (out-of-bounds memory access) or maybe remote code execution by inserting a mobile device into a personal computer through a USB cable.

Upstream bug report:

https://sourceforge.net/p/libmtp/mailman/message/35727918/

Created libmtp tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1465043]


Created libmtp11 tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: epel-6 [bug 1465042]

Created libmtp tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1465044]


Created libmtp11 tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: epel-6 [bug 1465045]

Created libgphoto2 tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1466791]

Stefan, can you please explain how the libmtp flaw is related to the newly
added/mentioned libgphoto2 tracker bug? Does libgphoto2 bundle libmtp?

(In reply to Robert Scheck from comment #4)
> Stefan, can you please explain how the libmtp flaw is related to the newly
> added/mentioned libgphoto2 tracker bug? Does libgphoto2 bundle libmtp?

Hi Robert,

I've not tested this, so I can't 100% claim that libgphoto2 is also affected. However, I've noticed the following commits in libgphoto2 and at least one of them seems related enough to handle them as a part of this:

https://github.com/gphoto/libgphoto2/commit/203df81b9d97e820411e1eb94ae08139af73bbd0
https://github.com/gphoto/libgphoto2/commit/e25b3983489cd290edef693e78c0af694d3cd010

Let me know if you have any further questions.

Statement:

Red Hat Product Security has rated this issue as having Low security impact. This issue is not currently planned to be addressed in future updates. For additional information, refer to the Issue Severity Classification: https://access.redhat.com/security/updates/classification/.

Patches:
https://sourceforge.net/p/libmtp/code/ci/aa7d91a789873a9d86969028e57f888a1241c085/
https://github.com/gphoto/libgphoto2/commit/203df81b9d97e820411e1eb94ae08139af73bbd0
https://github.com/gphoto/libgphoto2/commit/e25b3983489cd290edef693e78c0af694d3cd010

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of fedora-all.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=1465038,1465040

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new
